I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Macroeconomic context. India has been one of the world’s fastest growing economies 
during the last 5 years with average gross domestic product growth (at constant prices) of 6.8% 
from  FY2014–FY2019.1 However,  economic  growth  decelerated  since  the  first  quarter  of 
FY2018–FY2019 and slowed further following the outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-
19). The economy is estimated to contract by 9.0% in FY2020–FY2021, although it is expected 
to recover by 8% in FY2021–FY2022.2 The pandemic introduced many uncertainties on the 
medical, economic, social, and employment fronts. The proposed technical assistance (TA) 
facility will support processing of future lending projects and stand-alone TA projects to facilitate 
strategic studies and implement pilot projects related to the digital economy. These will support 
India’s post-COVID-19 economic recovery.  
 
2.  Renewed  attention  to  industrialization,  trade,  and  economic  growth.  The 
Government  of  India  (the  Government)  has  adopted  an  all-encompassing  industrialization 
strategy to improve economic growth and boost international trade. It is improving the availability 
of capital by including micro, small, and medium enterprise (MSME) lending in priority sector 
lending, changing the definition of MSMEs,3 and introducing a range of MSME financing schemes. 
The Government is also improving its infrastructure for coastal logistics and industrial corridors 
through the Sagarmala program, advancing the ease of doing business with state-level reforms 
to address regulatory bottlenecks; and enhancing access to affordable and sustainable energy 
through the Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission that targets establishment of 100GW of 
solar energy generation capacity by 2022 and the Ujwal DISCOM Assurance Yojana scheme to 
modernize distribution networks and institutions. To mitigate the adverse impact of the COVID-
19, the Government launched the Self-Reliant India4 initiative in May 2020, which complement 
the Make in India5 drive initiated in 2014 and promote bold measures in several sectors—coal, 
mining, power, and civil aviation. Most importantly, the initiative encourages small and large 
enterprises to innovate and grow.  
 
3.  Challenges  in  public  sector  management.  The  Government  has  progressively 
introduced reforms in public resource management and governance at the central and state 
levels. While some progress has been made, the pace of reforms was not uniform across states. 
The COVID-19 and resulting deteriorated fiscal profile has intensified the need for better public 
management and more effective public service delivery, calling for strengthening reforms to (i) 
improve public financial management (PFM) systems in lagging states, (ii) deepen structural 
reforms in progressive states, (iii) explore additional fiscal space, and (iv) ensure the effectiveness 
and sustainability of fiscal measures taken in response to the COVID-19.  
 
1  The World Bank. 2020. World Development Indicators (accessed 12 October 2020). 
2  ADB. 2020. Asian Development Outlook Update (accessed 22 October 2020). The World Bank projects India’s 
economy to contract by 9.6% in FY2020–21. 
3  Ministry of Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises. 2020. Ministry of MSME gears up to implement the New Norms of 
Classification of MSMEs (accessed 16 November 2020). The Government in June 2020 decided an upward revision 
of the MSME definition. It has also decided to include both investments made and turnover of the MSMEs in the 
definition. 
4  Self-Reliant India was announced with a number of initiatives for government reforms, business development and 
sector specific measures, aiming to make the country resilient against growing competition from the world and to 
support the vulnerable segments of the society that are adversely affected by COVID-19. 
5  Make in India is a Government of India initiative to facilitate India’s position as a global manufacturing hub. It is to 
attract investment and encourage innovation in the manufacturing sector, in addition to skills  enhancement, 
intellectual property rights protection and infrastructure development.

2 
4.  Finance sector needs further strengthening. Although the finance sector in India is 
more advanced than in other South Asian countries, effectiveness of financial intermediation 
needs to be further enhanced to meet the requisite long-term financing for economic and social 
infrastructures, as well as for risk capital to support entrepreneurial activities, to move to the next 
stage of economic development. Continued efforts are needed to ensure banking sector stability, 
promote innovative banking practices, and develop a broader and deeper capital market. The 
Government’s financial and regulatory support is necessary to stimulate private sector financing 
in the current market environment where investors are risk-averse because of COVID-19. 
 
5.  Growing importance of Digital India for inclusive outcomes. India is on its path to 
digital transformation through the Digital India program.6 The country is working on improving 
financial inclusion for the poor and vulnerable through digital payment systems. COVID-19 has 
further emphasized the need to digitize payments for safe and efficient economic transactions. 
The National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI), incorporated in 2008, has been authorized 
to partner with the banking sector to operationalize the electronic payment and settlement 
systems. It introduced, digital payment systems, such as the Aadhaar7 enabled Payment System 
and BHIM Aadhaar, to increase accessibility and adoptability of banking services amongst 
underserved  citizens  and  merchants.  Many  other  innovative  solutions8 are  currently  under 
discussion to increase adoption of digital payments among a broad range of stakeholders, raising 
potential to drive the government’s financial inclusion program.  
6.  ADB’s solutions-oriented approaches: industries and trade. Under ADB’s Country 
Partnership Strategy (CPS) for India 2018–2022,9 ADB operations have increasingly focused on 
delivering a comprehensive solutions, such as supporting the development of economic corridors 
by improving the investment climate and integrating a range of infrastructure developments—
transport  and  public  services  for  urban  areas,  industries,  and  trade—with  regulatory  and 
institutional reforms. Programs in this area are extended to multiple states, aiming to enhance 
domestic economic competitiveness for participation in global value chains. 
 
7.  Public sector management and finance sector development. The CPS envisages 
supporting several states to strengthen public expenditure management, domestic resource 
mobilization, and monitoring and evaluation. It also emphasizes on catalyzing private sector 
financing  for  infrastructure  projects  through  finance  sector  development.  ADB  had  earlier 
developed a successful business model to enhance financial intermediations through the India 
Infrastructure Finance Company Limited (IIFCL) and Indian Renewable Energy Development 
Agency  Limited  (IREDA)  to  finance  projects  particularly  under  public–private  partnership 
arrangements.10 Further promotion of the successful business model to non-traditional sectors, 
such as health care, is currently being explored, along with programs to design innovative 
financial  schemes and instruments  such  as  credit  enhancement  products for  infrastructure 
investments, to crowd-in private sector financing, drawing expertise from ADB’s Private Sector 
 
6  The program is launched in 2015 to improve digital and/or internet infrastructure to ensure that the government 
services are available to people electronically. 
7  An identity number for the citizens of India-based on citizen’s biometric and demographic details.  
8  Some of these include fintech-based cashback solutions for small and marginal farmers to overcome deficiencies in 
subsidy schemes and entrench use of digital payment, iris-based biometric authentication solution to overcome 
issues around fingerprint mismatch, innovative programs to bring street food vendors on eCommerce platforms. 
9  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2018–2022—Accelerating Inclusive Economic Transformation. 
Manila. 
10 ADB. 2013. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Multitranche 
Financing Facility for the Accelerating Infrastructure Investment Facility in India. Manila; and ADB. 2015. Technical 
Assistance to the Government of India for the Capacity Building for the Renewable Energy Development Agency. 
Manila.

3 
Operations Department and Office of Public–Private Partnership.  
 
8.  Digital solutions. Given the growing demand for fintech-based payment systems and 
other  digital  solutions, ADB  operations  may  align  with  the relevant Government’s financial 
inclusion programs. Building on the existing partnership with NPCI,11 ADB may further support 
pilot projects and analytical studies to expand the digital program. This may help to comprehend 
the  benefits  and  challenges  of  emerging  digital  schemes  for  microfinance  institutions, 
microenterprises, and other entities; and assist in designing improved and scaled up facilities to 
provide better digital business solutions for small vendors. 
9.  The TA facility. The TA is listed in the country operations business plan (COBP), 2020–
2022.12 It will support the preparation of the investment projects included in the India COBPs and 
associated studies as requested by the implementing agencies and cleared by the Department of 
Economic  Affairs  (DEA),  covering  the  sectors  of  industries  and  trade,  public  resource 
management, finance, and digital solutions.  
 
10.  The TA facility approach is suitable as many of these projects are in the same sector—i.e. 
finance  or  industry  and  trade—and  thus  have  similar  requirements  for  preparation  and 
implementation. The TA will help (i) enhance the efficiency of project preparation and improve 
readiness for projects with limited processing resources; (ii) create synergies across projects; (iii) 
share experiences from different states working with the same team of consultants; (iv) enable 
exchange  of  knowledge  and  ideas  for  project  processing,  and  design  and  implementation 
readiness; and (iv) strengthen coordination among various technical inputs and capacity building 
opportunities. Overall, the TA will reduce transaction and time costs compared to the resources 
required for separate stand-alone transaction TA projects.  
 
11.  Finance Plus. For the success of public sector management, finance, and multisector 
development projects, it is critical to provide policy advice to key stakeholders based on upstream 
strategic studies, and to develop downstream program execution mechanisms with capacity 
development support for implementing agencies. The TA will provide additional resources for both 
upstream  and  downstream  preparatory  work  to  improve  the  quality  of  project  design  and 
readiness.  
 
B.   Outputs and Activities 
 
12.  The TA will have the following three outputs to support the preparation of ensuing projects. 
 
13.  Output 1: Quality project design achieved. The TA will provide technical expertise to 
undertake diagnostic studies for efficient designing of potential ADB-funded projects. The scope 
of activities will include (i) analytical studies, such as sector assessment, gap analysis, demand 
assessment through surveys, and stakeholder analysis; (ii) identification of priority projects’ 
scopes and activities; (iii) support to small-scale pilot projects; (iv) climate risk screening and/or 
climate change assessment and climate risk and vulnerability assessment; and (v) feasibility 
studies as required for the ensuing projects. 
 
14.  Output 2: Quality due diligence achieved. The TA will provide technical expertise for 
procurement risk assessment, financial management assessment, financial analysis, economic 
 
11 ADB. 2020. Technical Assistance to the Government of India for Promoting Regional Partnerships for Adoption of 
Fintech and Digital Payments Systems: Institutional Support for National Payments Corporation of India. Manila 
(currently being processed).  
12 ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: India, 2020–2022. Manila.

4 
assessment, environment assessment, involuntary resettlement, indigenous peoples, and other 
social dimensions to support the preparation of investment projects for potential ADB financing. 
Activities  will  include  support  for  (i)  procurement  risk  assessment,  procurement  framework 
development, and contract administration; (ii) financial management assessment; (iii) financial 
sustainability evaluation and financial analysis; (iv) economic analysis; (v) safeguards documents 
on environmental considerations, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples; (vi) climate 
change  adaptation  and  mitigation  measures;  and  (vii)  gender  and  poverty  analysis, 
socioeconomic baseline data gathering, and gender action plans preparation.  
 
15.  Output 3: Capacity of implementing agencies strengthened. The TA will provide 
technical expertise and capacity building to selected implementing agencies for future projects to 
enhance the implementation and sustainability of investments. Consultants will provide  the 
support and will focus on enhancing the quality of project implementation and monitoring by 
supporting additional surveys and/or studies, seminars, workshops, and on-the-job training for 
staff from executing and implementing agencies across multiple projects. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 1. The TA facility’s scope will encompass other activities that are not covered by the 
associated TA projects of ensuing projects and will be consistent with the ensuing TA projects’ 
outputs and outcomes.  
 
17.  The government agencies responsible for each project will provide counterpart support in 
the form of counterpart staff, office space, office supplies, project-related information, and other 
in-kind contributions. The Government was informed that the approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to financing any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The DEA in the Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency of the TA facility. 
Government departments or agencies responsible for each project will be the implementing 
agencies for the TA, subject to the approvals of the DEA and ADB. ADB will administer the TA 
facility through the Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division of the South Asia 
Department and will work closely with the executing and implementing agencies of the ongoing 
and planned pipeline projects. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division will 
select, administer, evaluate, and supervise the consultants’ outputs for the projects, and work with 
the relevant line departments for all activities related to the TA.  
 
19.  The TA facility will be implemented from January 2021 to December 2023. Disbursements 
under the TA facility will be in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). 
  
20.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
21.  Consulting services. The TA facility will provide an initial 41 person-months of consulting 
services  (14  person-months  international  and  27  person-months  national)13 to  support  the 
preparation of projects. The consultants will be recruited using individual consultant selection 
based on the requirements of each project being prepared or implemented. Individual consultant 
selection, rather than firm selection, is considered appropriate because the TA facility involves 
multiple activities that are not necessarily interdependent and will require a varied range of 
consultants  and  services.  However,  where  suitable,  recruitment  through  a  firm  might  be 
considered. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.14  
 
E.  Governance 
 
22.  Because  ADB  will  administer  the  TA  facility,  the  risks  to  financial  management, 
procurement capacity, and integrity during the TA facility implementation are assessed to be low. 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
India for Enhancing Capacity to Design and Implement Public Resource Management, Finance, 
and Multisector Development Projects, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
13 The TA facility savings may be used for additional consultant inputs, if necessary. 
14 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
